I suppose this could have gone in the open forum, society, or even philosophy I guess, but I suppose it's just as well to put it here.
 
 This is something I have internal debates about constantly, so I thought I'd see what everybody here thought.
 
 How do you define art?
 
 I realize that is avery open and broad question, but that, I suppose, is part of the struggle.
 
 What do you yall think? I'll weigh in when I have thoughts on specific issues because to write my entire internal debate here would probably be very long and hard to understand.

Art - arranging colors in a manner such that it bolsters the sale value of an otherwise useless product.
Mach

Heh, two good answers back to back!
 
 OK, I'll take a half-way serious stab at it, but I'll limit it to pictures (visual, static art)
 
 The human mind is not some blank sponge ready to soak up stuff.
 Our brain evolved, like it or not, for a purpose, survival primarily it seems, and the myriad of complexities that go along with it.
 
 Ultimately, having "feelings" or getting "impressions" when observing things is part of how our mind is built. It serves us well. It helps us identify hot memebers of the opposite sex who will give our offspring a good chance to also be "hot" and better at reproducing (OK, not so serious), we fear things like the shape of a snake, even at an age before we've seen or heard what a snake is (negative response), we can get dizzy looking at some art, and colors in general are supposed to have some impact on mood.
 
 The net result is, once we were aware that we got some "feeling", ideally pleasure, from visual stimuli, we tried to get some more pleasure. Ultimately what works in art is what works. It's not a complete science, by any means...to turn art into a pure work of science would require us to figure out the entire human body first..which is a very long way off. So we're left with trial and error. Here (scribble scribble), like this? No..ok..how about this?
 
 That's the pleasure aspect. Another aspect is the rational aspect. The "meaning" a particular work of art has to the observer. Think TIME magainze photos that seem to "capture" a feeling or emotion, or represent some quality that we hold dear.
 
 I liked JP and DZs answer better :/, and putting the two together, it basically says the same thing "feels good, some people like it".
 
 -Mach
Master_Shake

Art is like pornography. I can't define it, but I know it when I see it. :)

 
 Stealing from Supreme Court justices now are we?

Please don't just limit yourselves to visual art everyone out there in forumland. And Mach, if we could turn art into a complete science it wouldn't be art anymore.

 What do you yall think? I'll weigh in when I have thoughts on specific issues because to write my entire internal debate here would probably be very long and hard to understand.

 This is a very interesting question: only yesterday I read that the "most important work of art in the 20th century" was a ready-made urinal exhibited (by Marcel Duchamp and entitled "Fountain") - in the opinion of certain art critics and collectors, etc. 
 If we focus on "modern art", we seem to have arrived at a point where the definition of a work of "art" can be whatever certain influential critics and associated "experts" say it is.
emclean

What is art? 
 
 he is the IT guy i call when my PC locks up.
Anastasia

I love art...
 I think it comes in so many forms.. visual, audible etc..
 I have been lucky that pretty much my whole working life has been in some form of art. I was a Cake decorator for almost 12 years.. I tattooed for some years and now I work in the entertainment industry doing Key art...(movie posters) I only wish I had more time to pursue more painting and drawing.
 I cannot say that I have a favorite medium as I pretty much enjoy it all, I think I relate to "darker" art more though. I love scary stuff, gothic art... and the way wacky stuff.
 Ever since I was a little kid, I was drawing.. sold my first painting in the 7th grade for $300.. That was cool.
 But the last 10 years raising a family has taken the time away for me, but it is still in my heart, and one day I will have my art studio and the time to explode:)
 There is one painting for some reason has a very special place in my heart, and not for any religious purpose, because as you all know I am not religious. Stomer did a painting called "The mocking of christ" and I adore it, there is something about the face of one of the characters that I love. I always said if I were to get a color tattoo, it would be that painting....All of my tattoos now are Maori, Marquesan, Borneo ..all done in black...

 Even a blind squirrel finds an acorn occasionally. In that instance, the Supreme Court made a profound proclamation. :)

Bono was recently quoated as saying "art is to chase away the ugliness." I don't know if I agree with tho.
 
 At it's most simple - art is how we express our creativity.
 
 People will argrue to death about what does and does not constitute a work of art, and the answer to this question can never be found - since what touches each person is never the same.
 
 I need music most and could usually care less about the lyrics. However I am fond of Bono, The Boss and Dylan for words - oh and old Bill Shakespeare. For my eyes I love Rembrandt and the Impressionists. Ansel Adams is my favorite photographer.

I like old Dylan, Springstein (early Jersey Years) and Shakespeare as well (even took a Shakespeare class in college which was unusual for science majors)....and Ansel Adams and his B&W Zone System is my favorite. Moonrise-Hernanzez, New Mexico was probably his finest effort, too.
SodGom

Art is something that tingles our senses and is an expression of the artist.
 
 Someone who is passionate about anything can call it their art.
 
 A mechanic who prides himself on fixing ny problem on any day.
 
 A musician who plays alone, a NASCAR driver, a professional gambler.
 
 Art isnt always for gerneral public, and soley for the enjoyment of the artist.
 
 An artist is someone who has a specialized ability in something. Someone that can do something others can hardly dream about and make it look easy.
 
 Joe Montana was an artist, Muhamid Ali, even Bill Clinton.

 I disagree, you're going way broad here. Passion is certainly a very important aspect of art, but I don't believe it is it's single defining component. NASCAR drivers, gambler, mechanics, atheletes, and politicians are not artists simply because they care about or are good at what they do. There is a difference between skill and artistry.

OccamsRazor

One of the most interesting things about art is how it can define a person according to their likes and dislikes.
 
 For example if I saw I like Da Vinci it gives an impression all of its own to the reader, even if you know very little of me.
 
 If I say I like Roy Lichenstein and Ralph Steadman it creates another very different impression of myself to you.
 
 It can also present paradox and contradiction within exisiting norms of taste. If I say I like Mozart and Nirvana but Beethoven and Alice in Chains is rubbish some people might find such a view difficult to relate too.
 
 Fascinating stuff.
jim's trucking

Art is whatever the artist thinks it is. Art is whatever the beholder thinks it is. I've been to art shows where trash was on display. I've seen stories about "art" that would make trash look like real art. (The crucifix in a jar of urine fits this bill.)
 
 To some, Picasso was not an artist, but a childish, haphazard doodler. Equally disdainful things have been said of the Dutch masters who painted with superlative 
 realism. Dali was a genius at warping reality to the point it seemed reasonable.
 
 Visual art is more easily categorized as good and bad because it is less subject to multiple interpretations. Audio art is more likely to have a wider range of valuations because our tastes in music are more varied than our interpretations of physical appearance and correct form. Culinary art is as varied as our tastebuds.
 
 That's why they make chocolate and vanilla.
 
 In short, I just about agree with the definition that art is wherever you find it...and you can find it almost anywhere.
georged

 What was interesting to me about Picasso's artistic ability was a news reporter many, many years ago casting doubt about Picasso's interpretation of art. The reporter, obviously a realist, was left dumbfounded when Picasso quickly penned an anatomically perfect horse at full gait in a matter of minutes. What people see is not always what's obvious to others, regardless of the subject.

Yes. I don't remember the name of the artist, but once upon a time a king sent an envoy to give a far away artist a test to see if he was good enough to commission for some royal painting. The artist painted, with one continuous stroke, a perfect circle and sent it to the king. He was hired.

Art is anything that is either painted, drawn, written, performed, sang, presented, shown, played (not in a sports sence) or some how exspressed. It can be art wheather or not it's liked by so many number of people. For example with that...
 Jazz...Jazz is an art. I personally can't stand jazz, but it's an art.
 I do think that rock is an art. While some one who listens to only country would say that I'm uncultured maybe.
 Many people enjoied Lord Of The Rings. I personally didn't but it's still an art form.
 Jurassic Park was an art form and I'm one of few people that really liked the trillogy.
 Movies, books, plays/musicals, drawings, paintings, television, comidy/tradgidy, music, and the like I would consider to be art.

 Yes, all of these things can be art, but aren't automatically art simply because they fall under something else that is under the general heading of "artform." :)
Bell

Art is the product of expression.
 
 I looked at Dictionary.com to see what their definition of art is. I was amused by the first definition:
 
 -ard or -art
 suff. 
 One that habitually or excessively is in a specified condition or performs a specified action: drunkard. 
 
 The noun form was defined firstly as: Human effort to imitate, supplement, alter, or counteract the work of nature. 
 
 Interesting; the inclusion of the aspect of 'nature'.
 
 
Many people enjoied Lord Of The Rings. I personally didn't but it's still an art form.

 
 What did you not like about it? I haven't met many people who didn't enjoy it.

What did you not like about it? I haven't met many people who didn't enjoy it.

 Let me just say that I did give Lord Of The Rings a chance. I personally couldn't get into it. I watched the trilogy and found it in my oppinion to be about a bunch of guys fighting over a piece of jewlery.
 Also, I have some problem getting into the fantasy genre, especially the epic ones. I personally couldn't get that much into it until about the second or third ending of Return Of The King. I did think they got better with each movie, but for me the first one was a little boring and the second one was just weird.
 But hey, please don't take anything personally. I'm a Star Trek fan (and Jurassic Park fan) and a lot of people don't get them (or annoyed) respectively. In other words, it's personal taste.
 
 
 You know, like artistic opinion.

 I like both. I watched the original Star Trek series before snndication and many times since. I never really got into "Next Generation" though. A buddy of mine dubbed it accurately "space meetings". Little action, lots of talk.
 I did get into Enterprise and was sorry to see it end. There was lots of action in that series.
 
 Having read all of JRR Tolkein's Hobbit books, I found the movies to be very enjoyable. Since I read them in college almost 30 years ago (instead of text books), I don't recall how true they were to the books, however.
 
 I'm waiting for someone to do a Foundations Trilogy since I'm also a big Asimov fan. emoticon_xgood

I like both.

 What I meant was that they are from two different genres. One is Sci-Fi and the other is Fantasy. I don't see why that connection is expected. I also enjoy movies like Indiana Jones. But there is no connection suggesting that some one who likes Star Trek automatically likes Indiana Jones or vissa-versa. Ofcourse, most of the time, Sci-Fi gets placed with other genres. I've seen Sci-Fi paired as "Sci-Fi/Adventure" "Sci-Fi/Horror" "Sci-Fi/Fantasy" "Sci-Fi/Drama" a couple of times. [Speaking of which, I saw the movie Trekkeis II in which they talk about a production of Romeo&Juliette as portraied by the Star Trek race that is half black and half white.(Anyone not know what species I'm refering to, ask a Star Trek fan, and yes, if need be, quote this and ask me or anyone else through here.)]
 Anyway, that's just my take on it. I didn't mean that you can't like both. I mean I don't see a connection as to why it would be automatically suggested that you will like one because you like the other.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  What is art?
